questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: MRgFUS causes heat necrosis in fibroid
HiFU can be used in those who want to preserve fertility
Uterine artery embolization carries a risk of femoral artery injury
Uterine artery embolization causes avascular necrosis of the fibroid

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HiFU can be used by those who want to preserve fertility

 

Explanation:

HiFU, or High-Frequency Focused USG, uses heat to coagulate and necrose fibroid; it cannot be used by those who wish to preserve fertility.

 

Newer methods of fibroid management:

 

Uterine Artery Embolization (UAE)
  • Shrinks the fibroid by causing avascular necrosis (Option D)
  • Angiographic procedure in which uterine arteries are blocked using polyvinyl alcohol through the femoral artery
  • Minimally invasive
  • Risk of injury to the femoral artery (Option C)

MR-guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS)
  • Focused heat to coagulate and cause necrosis in fibroid (Option A)
  • Contraindicated in:
    • Uterine size >24 weeks.
    • Myoma size >10 cm.
    • Desire for future fertility

High-Frequency Focused USG (HiFU)
  • Focused heat to coagulate and cause necrosis in fibroid
  • Cannot be used if fertility is desired (Option B)

questions.text: A 65 year old postmenopausal woman and a 35 year old premenopausal woman present with abnormal uterine bleeding. Both patients undergo transvaginal sonography (TVS), which reveals endometrial polyps. The postmenopausal woman's polyp is 2 cm in size, while the premenopausal woman's polyp is 1.7 cm and is associated with recurrent bleeding and infertility. What is the most appropriate management for each patient?

choices.text: Observation and follow-up in 6 months for both patients.
Hysteroscopic polypectomy for the postmenopausal woman and diagnostic hysteroscopy for the premenopausal woman.
Diagnostic hysteroscopy for the postmenopausal woman and hysteroscopic polypectomy for the premenopausal woman.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hysteroscopic polypectomy for both patients.

 

Explanation:

Hysteroscopic polypectomy is recommended for postmenopausal women due to the higher malignancy risk. In premenopausal women, it is indicated for polyps causing abnormal bleeding, >1.5 cm, or associated with infertility. It is the preferred method for removing endometrial polyps.

 

Postmenopausal Women: Should undergo hysteroscopic polypectomy regardless of symptoms due to a higher risk of malignancy.

Premenopausal Women: Hysteroscopic polypectomy is indicated if the polyp

  • Causes abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Causes infertility
  • Is multiple
  • Is larger than 1.5 cm
  • Is a prolapsed polyp
  • Is a recurrent polyp

 

Diagnostic Hysteroscopy

In Premenopausal Women, if hysteroscopic polypectomy is not performed, diagnostic hysteroscopy should be done.

 

Post-Polypectomy Treatment

Hormone Therapy: Premenopausal women may receive progesterone or continuous GnRH therapy to manage endometrial overgrowth. However, bleeding may recur after stopping treatment.

questions.text: Which investigation finding can help differentiate an endometrial polyp from a fibroid?

choices.text: Fibroids show a single feeder vessel on Doppler ultrasound.
Endometrial polyps have a peripheral rim of vascularity on Doppler ultrasound.
Hysteroscopy reveals fibroid polyps as firm and pale, endometrial polyps as soft and pink.
Saline infusion sonography (SIS) is not useful in here.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hysteroscopy reveals fibroid polyps as firm and pale, and endometrial polyps as soft and pink.

 

Explanation:

Hysteroscopy allows direct visualization of the uterine cavity, enabling differentiation between fibroid polyps, which are firm and pale, and endometrial polyps, which are soft and pink.

 

Feature

Endometrial Polyp

Submucous fibroid

Appearance

Pink, small (1-2 cm), single or multiple, with a pedicle

Paler, firm, with broad base (sessile)/ pedunculated.

Microscopic Features

Endometrial glands and stroma, covered by columnar epithelium

Fibroids consist of spindle-shaped cells organized into interwoven bundles, creating a well-defined lesion.

Malignancy

Usually benign, can undergo secondary malignant changes

Generally benign

Common Symptoms

Menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, postmenopausal bleeding, postcoital bleeding

DIAGNOSIS

Doppler ultrasound

Typically show a single feeder vessel. (Option B)

Show a characteristic peripheral rim of vascularity with penetrating vessels. (Option A)

Hysteroscopy

Soft, smooth. reddish/pinkish mass with a slender stalk, originating from the endometrial lining.

Firm, pale mass with a broad base or stalk, from the myometrium, with prominent vessels, distorting the uterus.

Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS) or sonohysterogram

Clarifies diagnoses and differentiates endometrial polyps from fibroids when TVS shows a thick or irregular endometrium.

questions.text: A 48 year old woman reports six months of heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain. Physical exam shows an enlarged, irregular uterus. Initial ultrasound suggests uterine fibroids, but differentiation from adenomyosis is unclear. What is the best investigation to accurately distinguish between fibroids and adenomyosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Magnetic Resonance Imaging

 

Explanation:

MRI is the best investigation to distinguish between uterine fibroids and adenomyosis when ultrasound is inconclusive. It provides detailed imaging with superior contrast resolution and tissue characterization.

 

Investigations for Uterine Fibroids

 

Ultrasound
  • Key Diagnostic Tool: Identifies fibroids and differentiates them from other conditions
  • Well-defined, rounded, hypoechoic (darker) appearance
  • Cystic spaces indicate degeneration
  • Vascularity: Assessed with Doppler ultrasound
  • 3D Ultrasound: Detailed size, location, and number of fibroids

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) & Sonosalpingography

Evaluate fallopian tube patency and detect submucous fibroids. (Option A)

MRI

Detailed pelvic imaging, especially for virgins, and older women, and differentiating between fibroids, adenomyosis, and sarcomas

Hysteroscopy

Diagnostic and therapeutic allows direct visualization and potential removal of submucous fibroids.

Dilation & Curettage (D&C)

Obtains endometrial tissue for biopsy in abnormal uterine bleeding, ruling out cancer in menstrual disorders or postmenopausal bleeding. (Option C)

Intravenous Pyelography (IVP)

Visualize the urinary tract when a broad ligament fibroid is suspected to check for ureter compression

Laparoscopy
  • Confirm diagnosis when other methods are inconclusive (Option D)
  • Investigate associated conditions like PID or endometriosis
  • Assist in procedures to prevent uterine perforation

questions.text: A 35 year old woman with a history of early menarche, nulliparity, and a maternal history of uterine fibroids presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and occasional pelvic pain. A pelvic ultrasound confirms uterine fibroid polyps. Which factor in her history is most strongly associated with her increased risk of developing uterine fibroid polyps?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All the above

 

Explanation:

Early menarche, nulliparity and family history are associated with an increased risk of developing fibroids.


 

Risk Factors for Fibroid & endometrial Polyps

  • Early Menarche (Option A) >> Nulliparity/Low Parity (Option B)
  • Estrogen and progesterone promote fibroid growth; fibroids grow during pregnancy and shrink after menopause.
  • Genetics: Familial occurrences suggest a hereditary component. (Option C)
  • AUB
  • Tamoxifen use
  • HRT: Higher incidence in postmenopausal women on HRT due to continuous endometrial stimulation by estrogen.
  • Obesity: Increased estrogen exposure
  • Multiple Polyps: Independent risk factor for premalignant and malignant changes.

 

Clinical Presentation of Uterine Polyps:

Endometrial Polyp

Uterine Fibroid
  • Menstrual Disturbances: menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, intermenstrual bleeding, postmenopausal bleeding
  • Postcoital Bleeding (if the polyp protrudes through the cervical canal)
  • Asymptomatic in some cases.
  • Menstrual Disturbances: Similar to endometrial polyps with heavy and irregular bleeding
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Infertility and pregnancy loss (with Submucous fibroid polyps)
  • Vaginal Discharge (with pedunculated submucous fibroids)
  • Asymptomatic (often an incidental finding)

questions.text: A 36 year old woman undergoes an operative hysteroscopy. What early complication can be expected after this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fluid overload

 

Explanation:

Fluid overload is an early complication of operative hysteroscopy.

 

Complications of operative hysteroscopy:

 

Early complications

Distention media related:

  • Fluid overload (Option A)
  • Hyponatremia
  • Gas embolism
  • Glycine toxicity

Operative:

  • Uterine perforation
  • Hemorrhage
  • Thermal burns
  • Infection

Late complications
  • Scar rupture in the next pregnancy (Option C)
  • Uterine adhesions (Option D)
  • Hematoma (Option B)
  • Post-ablation sterilization syndrome

questions.text: A 35 year old woman has been diagnosed with a submucosal fibroid. She is considered for a hysteroscopic myomectomy. Monopolar electrosurgical loop is used during her procedure. Which of the following findings made her a suitable candidate for hysteroscopic myomectomy and what distention fluid was used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type 1 fibroid; glycine

 

Explanation:

FIGO type 0 or 1 submucosal fibroids, are removed by hysteroscopic myomectomy. Glycine is the choice of distension fluid due to the use of a monopolar electrosurgical loop.

Fluid distention media is used for distention of uterine cavity during hysteroscopy.

  • Glycine
    • It is a non-conducting fluid, electrolyte free media.
    • It offers more clarity of vision as compared to normal saline media.
    • Monopolar electrosurgical instruments can be used.
    • Risk of fluid overload complications & hyponatremia is more as compared to normal saline media, as glycine is hypotonic & electrolyte free.

 

  • Normal saline
    • It is a conducting fluid, electrolyte media.
    • Only bipolar electrosurgical instruments can be used with this media (not monopolar).
    • Since it is isotonic, there is less fluid overload complications as compared to glycine media.

Therefore, assessment of fluid deficit is important during operative hysteroscopy procedures. Amount of distention fluid being pushed into the uterine cavity and the amount of fluid escaping out is closely monitored, to track how much of fluid deficit (the fluid getting absorbed into the systemic circulation) can be safely allowed.

The procedure is immediately stopped, if the fluid deficit is more than 1 - 1.5 liters with glycine & 2 - 2.5 liters with normal saline media.

 

Type 2 fibroid; normal saline (Option A): Type 2 fibroid cannot be taken up for hysteroscopic myomectomy however monopolar electrosurgical loop will work with glycine.

 

Type 1 fibroid; normal saline (Option C): type 1 fibroid can be taken up for hysteroscopic myomectomy. However normal saline cannot be used with a monopolar electrosurgical loop.

 

Type 2 fibroid; glycine (Option D): Type 2 fibroid cannot be taken up for hysteroscopic myomectomy however monopolar electrosurgical loop will work with glycine.

questions.text: A 34 year old lady is concerned about her upcoming myomectomy operation. Which of the following is not a complication of this operation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Infertility

 

Explanation:

Infertility is not a complication of myomectomy. Myomectomy is performed to preserve fertility and remove fibroid from the uterus.

 

Complications of myomectomy:

  • Hemorrhage (Option B)
    • Intraoperative
    • Postoperative
  • Infection
  • Adhesions (Option A)
  • Injury to bladder or ureter (Option D)
  • Injury to intestine
  • Injury to fallopian tubes

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used to minimize blood loss in myomectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) GnRH agonist given post-operatively


Explanation:

GnRH agonist is given preoperatively to reduce bleeding. It reduces tumour vascularity and reduces blood loss during the procedure.

Techniques for reducing blood loss in myomectomy:

  • Pre-operative GnRH agonist reduces bleeding.
  • Pre-operative correction of anaemia (Option A)
  • Arrange blood and FFP. Autotransfusion is also a possibility for major surgeries.
  • Intra-op methods used to stop bleeding:
    • Uterine clamp (myoma clamp)
    • Tourniquet (Option C)
    • Injection of vasopressin called Pitressin (Option D)
    • Avoid entering the uterine cavity

questions.text: A 32 year old woman has been trying to conceive for 2 years. She is diagnosed with uterine fibroid. She is interested in having a myomectomy. What tests should be performed before confirming the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

CBC, Hysteroscopy and Husband’s semen analysis must be performed to assess the requirement of myomectomy to preserve fertility.


 

Prerequisites to myomectomy:

  • Hemoglobin > 10 g/dL (CBC)
  • Semen analysis of husband to rule out the cause of infertility or sub-fertility
  • Hysteroscopy to exclude tubal block, submucous fibroid, or polyp.

questions.text: A 38 year old nulliparous woman came with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding and recurrent pregnancy loss. She desires to get pregnant. On USG, submucosal fibroid is seen. Which of the following is the preferred treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Myomectomy

 

 

Explanation:

 

  • Myomectomy is the preferred treatment of choice for submucosal fibroid in a female who desires to preserve fertility. It can be done via hysteroscopy or laparoscopy.
  • Unlike other treatments such as hysterectomy, uterine artery embolization (UAE) or MRgFUS, myomectomy maintains the structural integrity of the uterus.

 

 

Hysteroscopy

Laparoscopy

Indication
  • Fibroid of 3–4 cm in diameter
  • Type 0 submucosal
  • Type 1 submucosal
  • Subserous
  • Intramural fibroids
  • Type 2 submucosal

Instrument used
  • Electrocautery
  • Electro-diathermy
  • Harmonics
  • Laser
  • Extracorporeal sutures

 

 

 

Hysterectomy (Option A): It is the definitive surgery in those over 40 years old when the family is complete.

 

 

 

Uterine artery embolization (Option C): It leads to shrinkage of fibroid. Polyvinyl alcohol/gel foam is inserted in the uterine artery via the femoral artery. It is contraindicated when fertility is desired.

 

 

MRgFUS (Option D): MR-guided focussed ultrasound uses ultrasound energy to cause necrosis of myoma. It has a risk of endometritis and burns. It is contraindicated when fertility is desired.

questions.text: A 38 year old nulliparous woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and painful menstrual cramps. Ultrasound confirms the presence of multiple uterine fibroids. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic factor contributing to the development of her fibroids?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) IGF and VEGF

 

Explanation:

Fibroids originate from a single, neoplastic smooth muscle cell (myocyte) in the myometrium.

 

Growth factors, particularly Insulin-like Growth Factor (IGF) and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) are implicated in stimulating the proliferation of these myocytes, leading to fibroid development.

Fibroids

Risk factors

Protective Factors
  • Increasing age >50 (80%).
  • Hyperestrogenic state: Early menarche, Nulliparity, Obesity, ↑ body mass index (BMI).
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
  • Black women.
  • High-fat diet, Red meat.
  • Family history.
  • Late menarche.
  • Multiparity. (Option B)
  • Early Menopause. (Option A)
  • Combined oral contraceptives (COC).
  • Smoking. (Option D)

questions.text: A 39 year old woman presents with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic discomfort. Pelvic examination reveals a palpable irregular mass consistent with fibroids, and USG reveals distortion of the uterine cavity. She wishes to avoid surgery and seeks medical management. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ulipristal

 

Explanation:

Ullipristal reduces the size of the fibroid and further alleviates its symptoms of pain, bleeding, and pressure by antagonising progesterone receptors in the fibroid.

 

Medical management of fibroids:

 

Drug

Features

NSAIDs (Option A)
  • Reduces pain, not the bleeding

Tranexamic acid (Option B)
  • Antifibrinolytic agent
  • Reduces bleeding, not the pain

GnRH analogues- Leuprorelin, Goserelin
  • Suppresses estrogen and progesterone levels after the initial flare of symptoms due to increased estrogen and progesterone
  • Decreases fibroid size and vascularity
  • Also used before myomectomy to reduce blood loss

GnRH antagonist- cetrorelix, ganirelix
  • Directly decreases estrogen and progesterone levels
  • Decreases fibroid size and vascularity

Mifepristone
  • Antagonises progesterone receptor in fibroid
  • Reduces bleeding

Ulipristal (Option C)
  • Selective Progesterone receptor modulator
  • Reduces the size of fibroid by antagonising progesterone receptors

Mirena (LNG IUD) (Option D)
  • Reduces blood loss
  • Not recommended when the uterus is> 12 weeks in size, or there is a distortion of the cavity.

questions.text: A 48 year old, multiparous woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and a sensation of pelvic fullness. Her menstrual cycles have become increasingly irregular over the past year. On clinical exam the uterus is enlarged to 16 weeks size. A pelvic USG confirms the presence of multiple uterine leiomyomas. Endometrial aspiration is performed which shows normal secretory endometrium. The woman is not keen on a major surgical procedure. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists

 

Explanation:

Based on the above scenario, the mentioned perimenopausal women should be treated conservatively and medical management can be offered.

The menopausal transition of fibroid:

  • Estrogen and progesterone play an important role In the development of uterine fibroid.
  • Fibroid is an estrogen-sensitive tumor, which grows in the presence of estrogen.
  • After menopause, since estrogen and progesterone level decreases, the fibroid regresses in size.
  • In perimenopausal women with symptomatic uterine fibroid, the patients should be treated conservatively as the tumour regresses after attaining menopause.
  • For symptomatic relief, treatment with NSAIDs, OCPs or GnRH agonists should be bridged between the perimenopausal and menopausal phases (Option B).

 

Myomectomy (Option A) is generally reserved for patients who prefer to remain fertile or those who wish to retain their uterus. But as mentioned the patient is not keen on a major surgical procedure, and medical management can be tried first.

 

Uterine artery embolization (Option C), is an angiographic procedure that obscures uterine blood flow and causes ischemia of the uterus. This conservative procedure can bebut  considered for select cases of women who wish to avoid surgery and have completed their child bearing But there are chances that an emergency hysterectomy may be needed for potential complications of the procedure itself; like infected fibroids, severe post-embolization syndrome, procedural failure). Therefore, women not prepared to accept this small risk of hysterectomy in the event of complications are not feasible candidates.

 

Hysterectomy (Option D) is a major surgical procedure that is usually performed as a last resort if the patient's symptoms do not improve or recurrences following medical therapy or there is suspicion of leiomyosarcoma.

questions.text: A 42 year old woman reports chronic pelvic pain, heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding, and lower abdominal fullness. Her pelvic exam shows an enlarged, irregular uterus. Which imaging modality best assesses the number, size, and location of uterine fibroids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Magnetic Resonance Imaging

 

Explanation:

 

Diagnosis of Leiomyoma:

Ultrasound (Option A) is the best initial modality for diagnosing leiomyoma but does not provide accurate information. Compared to MRI, it is most commonly used due to cost and availability reasons.

Hysterosonography (Option B) is most commonly used for submucosal fibroids in which the uterus is filled with sterile water and imaging is done.

CT scans (Option D) are less used due to lower soft tissue resolution than MRI and ultrasound.

questions.text: A 38 year old woman presents with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort, and frequent urination. On physical examination, her uterus is found to be irregularly enlarged. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Leiomyoma

Explanation:

Based on the above scenario, the patient is most likely having leiomyoma.

 

Leiomyoma:

Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle neoplasms that originate in myometrium.

 

Clinical features:

  • Asymptomatic (75%) - mostly an incidental finding
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding(AUB)(30%): Menorrhagia,metrorrhagia
  • Dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia
  • Subfertility
  • Pressure symptoms
    • Bladder symptoms: increased frequency or retention of urine
    • Rectal symptoms: constipation
  • Lower abdominal or pelvic pain or heaviness
  • Irregularly enlarged lower abdomen.

 

Endometriosis (Option A) also presents with pelvic pain and abnormal menstrual bleeding but an irregularly enlarged uterus is not seen.

 

An ovarian cyst (Option B) most commonly, is asymptomatic but increases the risk of ovarian torsion and presents with an adnexal mass but not an enlarged uterus.

 

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (Option D) is usually seen in obese women and presents with irregular menstrual bleeding along with hormonal symptoms such as hirsutism and acne.

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for red degeneration of fibroids in pregnant women?

choices.text: Immediate myomectomy to remove the fibroid
Conservative management with pain relief and supportive care
Administration of high-dose steroids to reduce inflammation and then surgical removal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Conservative care with pain relief and support

 

Explanation:

Red Degeneration:

  • Red degeneration, also known as carneous degeneration, is a complication of uterine fibroids that can occur during pregnancy.
  • This condition is most likely to arise during the second half of pregnancy and the puerperium, impacting an estimated 5-10% of women with uterine fibroids.
  • Pathophysiology: Blood supply is redirected to the developing fetus, resulting in decreased blood supply to the fibroid and subsequent degeneration.
  • Conservative management with pain relief and supportive care is the best course of management (option C).
  • It involves pain relief with NSAIDs or acetaminophen, hydration, and bed rest.

Immediate myomectomy (Option A) to remove the fibroid is not recommended as it poses a risk of fetal injury and uterine rupture.

Uterine artery embolization (Option B) is not recommended in pregnant women as it leads to fetal loss. It can be done in patients who are not pregnant and who do not desire future fertility.

Administration of high-dose corticosteroids (Option D) has no proven effect for treating degenerating fibroid.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents to the ER with sudden-onset severe lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, there is tenderness on palpation of the lower abdomen. Pelvic USG reveals a large heterogeneous mass in the myometrium with areas of necrosis and irregular margins. What is the most likely condition from the options given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Degeneration of fibroid

 

Explanation:

Based on the above scenario, the patient's symptoms are suggestive of degeneration of uterine fibroids.

 

Degeneration of Fibroid:

  • Degeneration is a secondary change seen in fibroids.
  • The most common symptom of degeneration is pelvic pain.

 

Type of degeneration

Pathophysiology

Hyaline degeneration

Accumulation of proteinous tissue

Cystic degeneration

Extreme fluid collection

Calcareous degeneration (womb stone)

Deposition of phosphates and carbonates in the periphery

Red degeneration (hemorrhagic)

Decrease in blood supply to the fibroid

 

Sarcomatous transformation (Option A) is a rare secondary change in leiomyoma, which may present with acute pelvic pain or a sudden increase in the size of the fibroid.

Ovarian torsion (Option C) presents with severe pelvic pain, fever and adnexal mass.

Atrophy of fibroids (Option D) usually occurs due to ageing and ischemia after menopause.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presents with complaints of lower abdominal pain and irregular menstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. On examination, a pelvic mass is palpable on the right side, confirmed to be a true broad ligament fibroid on imaging. Which of the following statements is not true regarding primary broad ligament fibroid?

choices.text: They arise from the broad ligament
Uterine vessels and ureter lie medial to the fibroid
Uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to the fibroid

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to the fibroid

Explanation:

Leiomyomas are the most common benign tumours of the uterus but may also occur outside of the uterus.

Broad ligament leiomyoma:

True/primary broad ligament fibroid

Pseudo/secondary broad ligament fibroid

Rare condition directly arising from the broad ligament (Option A&D)

More common condition that arises from the uterus but grows laterally.

Uterine vessels and ureter lies medial to the tumour (Option B)

Uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to the tumour (Option C)

Manifests as extrauterine pelvic mass and may compress the ureter, urethra, bladder and bowel causing bowel and bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: Identify the location of the fibroid marked C in the diagram.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Submucosal

 

Explanation:

The diagram is marked below:

FIGO Classification of Fibroids.
 

Type

Name

Submucosal

0

Pedunculated, Intracavity

1

<50% Intramural and rest in cavity

2

≥ 50% Intramural and a part in cavity

3

100% intramural but contacts endometrium

Intramural

4

Intramural

Subserosal

5

≥ 50% Intramural and partly in serosa

6

<50% Intramural and rest in serosa

7

Subserosal Pedunculated

Others

8

Other - Cervical, Parasitic

2-5

Hybrid - Present both in the cavity (type 2) and in the serosa (type 5)

questions.text: The 45-year-old multiparous woman underwent a hysterectomy for abnormal uterine bleeding after failed medical management. The uterus is firm and irregularly enlarged with multiple tumours in the myometrium with a characteristic whorled appearance on cut-section. HPE shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Uterine Fibroid

 

Explanation:

 

  • Uterine Fibroid presents with heavy bleeding, pelvic pain, and a firm, irregularly enlarged uterus.
  • Histopathology reveals interlacing bundles of smooth muscle cells with a characteristic whorled appearance.
  • Fibroids have an Eosinophilic cytoplasm and oval nuclei (cigar-shaped) with blunt ends.

Adenomyosis (Option A) is the presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, usually causing a uniformly enlarged and tender uterus. Histopathologically, adenomyosis shows endometrial glands and stroma interspersed within the myometrium.

 Endometrial Polyps (Option B) present with intermenstrual spotting rather than heavy bleeding. Histopathologically, endometrial polyps show irregularly shaped glands and a fibrous stroma, sometimes with blood vessels.

 Endometriosis (Option D) is endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, causing chronic pain and infertility, with histopathology showing ectopic endometrial glands and stroma.
